definition:
If a ring $(R,\,+,\,\cdot)$ left identity element $e$, i.e. if
$$e\cdot a = a \quad \forall a,$$ then $e$ is called the [*left
unity*]{} of $R$.

If a ring $R$ right identity element $e'$, i.e. if
$$a\cdot e' = a \quad \forall a,$$ then $e'$ is called the [*right
unity*]{} of $R$.

A ring may have several left or right unities (see e.g. the Klein
four-ring).

If a ring $R$ has both a left unity $e$ and a right unity $e'$, then
they must coincide, since $$e' = e\cdot e' = e.$$ This situation means
that every right unity equals to $e$, likewise every left unity. Then we
speak simply of a unity of the ring.
phrase: Left And Right Unity Of Ring
